content: Albatross.  Ilias's MFA Computer Art Thesis at the School of Visual Arts. The albatross (as immortalized by Charles Baudelaire) is a bird that, while unwieldy on the ground, shows its beauty in flight. Ilias's Albatross roams a room in a rather unwieldy manner, but accumulates a set of beautiful marks on a flat surface and in a virtual environment. (2005)
title: Albatross

content: Green Gym.  One night, as they passed a local gym, Ilias scoffed, "think of all the wasted energy. All these people could be powering electric appliances!" Arlene said, "That's a great idea, we should enter it into the NASA Create the Future Contest!" And the Green Gym design was born. (2006)
title: Green Gym

content:
Conflux Composite.  The Conflux Festival is an annual psychogeography festival held at NYU, and many of its events have explored the city through crowdsourced (in-situ) data collection; for example, an individual will log
(usually through a cell phone or mobile computer) a location where he notices a particular object. For the 2010 Conflux Fest, DuKode held "Conflux Composite," a workshop that will combined crowdsourced data with other types of New York City data– municipal vector-based data from NYC.gov's Bytes of
title: Conflux Composite

content:
CREATE @ NYU.  DuKode has entered an ongoing collaboration with the Consortium for Research and Evaluation of Advanced Technologies in Education (CREATE) at New York University. CREATE hosted DuKode's "Conflux Composite" mapping workshop in Fall 2010, and DuKode is helping CREATE to reshape its "Molecules and Minds" chemistry simulations for high school students, in a study supported by the Department of Education.
Below: screenshot from a draft version of a Molecules and Minds simulation.
title: CREATE @ NYU

content: Climate Central: Nuclear Reactors.  To mark the 25th Anniversary of the explosion at Chernobyl, Climate Central produced a multimedia package of articles, graphics, videos, and interactives. DuKode contributed this interactive that takes a closer look at Small Modular Reactors. This piece was featured in the April 2011 edition of Good Magazine.
title: Climate Central: Nuclear Reactors

content: Climate Central: Fires.  Climate Central released a Wildfires 2011 package in anticipation of the coming fire season. DuKode contributed several pieces, including data visualizations of high fire years in Montana and Nevada, and an infographic that contrasts these ecosystems.
title: Climate Central: Fires

content: "New York City's Foodshed" Poster.  New York City’s food system is locally served by areas from New England to the Mid-Atlantic states. New York food consumers are intricately linked to consumers throughout the surrounding areas and beyond. DuKode created a poster to examine complexities of the New York City food system, or foodshed. In creating this poster, we focused on creating a comprehensible static graphic with five dimensions of USDA Food Environment Atlas data. Development issues included visual design of 5-D data for easy
title: "New York City's Foodshed" Poster

content:
Water Underground.  http://sciencebulletins.amnh.org/?sid=e.v.water_underground.20120424&src=l
and
http://sos.noaa.gov/datasets/extras/groundwater_amnh.html
The rivers and lakes dataset used in this video is from BGR WHYMAP (World-wide Hydrogeological Mapping and Assessment Programme), as is the aquifer dataset.
The global freshwater storage data come from NASA's GRACE (Gravity Recovery and Climate Experiment).
The detailed maps of the southern United States are the output of a computer model that diagnoses drought
title: Water Underground

content:
Piraeus Tower.  GreekArchitects.gr and DuPont Hellas S.A. sponsored the architectural competition "Piraeus Tower 2010 - changing the face/facade reformation." The competition objectives were to investigate ways with which the Piraeus Tower–a 22-story, 84-meters tall building that is abandoned for more than 30 years–can be utilized and become an important architectural building, not only for the city of Piraeus, but for the whole metropolitan area of Athens.
"Wind.Light.Vision" is a proposal to enhance the Tower
title: Piraeus Tower

content: NeckFace.  Arlene's MFA Computer Art Thesis at the School of Visual Arts. When Arlene first moved to New York, a graffiti artist was tagging "NeckFace" all over the neighborhoods she frequented. This made her think of chickens. Her own NeckFace is a meditation on time management by way of fowl imagery and Rumi's poetry. Special thanks to performers Ed Kulzer and David Briggs, who weren't afraid to run around and into Arlene's squishy, crusty, even slightly slimy video installations and robotic objects. (20
title: NeckFace

content: SWAN Mobile Peripheral.  To explore the hardware and software options for making a wearable peripheral that connects to a pocket computing device, we made a fun mini-demo: a swan armband and 3D iOS software inspired by theatrical influences like Brazilian carnivals and the recent film Black Swan. A first user would wear the armband and control an openGL swan through his movement, while a second user could control the swan's environment through the iOS device. The Swan demo had its public premiere at the Lower East Side
title: SWAN Mobile Peripheral

content: Local Projects.  The media design firm Local Projects enlisted DuKode's help for some  of its upcoming science-related project proposals. DuKode created snail, neuron, and brain models at several tessellations for use with custom Augmented Reality environments created by Craig Kapp. (2010)
title: Local Projects

content: Studio 12.  Based in Athens, Greece, Studio 12 has worked on major buildings in that city and beyond. In addition to architectural rendering, Ilias created the Studio 12 web site. (1996-2002)
title: Studio 12

content: The Work of Beryl Sokoloff.  For more than four decades in downtown New York City, Beryl Sokoloff (1918-2006) transformed raw shapes, colors, and sound into cinematic orbits of wonder. Under the direction of Beryl's partner, Crista Grauer, Ilias was the creative director for the boxed set of Beryl Sokoloff's work. (2003-2006)
title: The Work of Beryl Sokoloff

content: The Power of Water.  The GA Media group submitted a proposal that included this animation to the Missouri Department of Natural Resources for an exhibit on "The Power of Water." The proposal included this animation and several storyboards, each depicting a body of water in different eras. (2009)
title: The Power of Water

content: Keeling Curve.  Charles Keeling's graph, first started in 1958, shows that while CO2 levels fluctuate month to month, they have increased from year to year. This animation was used in the Climate Central feature "What We Know For Sure." (2009)
title: Keeling Curve

content: My Nights With April.  This short documentary explores mores and choices on gender, race, and sexuality amongst twentysomethings near Washington, D.C. At the center of this exploration is April Stace: a white lesbian turned "straight" woman married to an Asian man, an artist turned theology student, and a true liberal who defies all these categories.
title: My Nights With April

content: Diversity and Distributions.  DuKode created the cover image for the January 2011 issue of Diversity and Distributions, A Journal of Biogeography. This image is a visualization of global ports' temperature and salinity similarities to those of the Greater Great Lakes Ecosystem. On top of this port data, DuKode drew a network of shipping routes to connect these global ports. This image was commissioned by Dr. Reuben Keller of the University of Chicago, lead author of the paper "Linking environmental conditions and ship moveme
title: Diversity and Distributions

content:
The Last Word.  We all start and abandon myriads of projects that are so nascent we can barely describe them. DuKode is no exception. Here is a collection of its sketches, orphans, and abandonware.
A picture made for a DVD cover (2006).
A funny sketch by Ilias (2009).
A flyer for a never-held book drive (2007).
Random cartoons by Arlene (2006).
title: The Last Word

content: Colony Colony Colonus.  A first visit to the Visayas region in the Philippines, Arlene's ancestral homeland, inspired this project. It consists of a video travelogue, a high-resolution mosaic of regional geodata, and a graphic story about her mom's youthful days as an anti-Marcos "weekend activist." (2007)
title: Colony Colony Colonus

content: Empty Man Icons.  Empty man is the ennui-prone character from the hartenios, protagonist of Ilias's graphic story series. Ilias produced a collection of Empty Man super-high-quality renders. You can download Empty Man for your own personal use! (2008)
title: Empty Man Icons

content: Common Ground.  This print, made for a Beijing Olympics-related art competition, shows two ways that Earth's health is measured: population density (seen on the land) and carbon monoxide levels (extruded into the air). CO levels are clearly higher in the more populated northern hemisphere. Data by NASA SVS. (2007)
title: Common Ground

content:
The Lumenhattio Project.  Lumenhattio is a stretchable glowing helmet cover that provides affordable, changeable style by day and safety light by night. The Lumenhattio comes in several styles and runs on inexpensive cell batteries. Whereas few cyclists own multiple helmets, most cyclists can own multiple Lumenhattios.
Bike-friendly cities tend to consider the bicycle as a vehicle in its own right, with its own street lanes and its own traffic rules. The Lumenhattio strengthens the bicycle's vehicular role by giving the
title: The Lumenhattio Project

content:
Topography Ceramics.  Inspired by our visualization projects that implement topography and maps through Maya CAD software, we've started to bring our visualizations into the physical world through hand-built and 3D-printed ceramics. Custom-mixed glazes will be algorithmically applied to represent climate-related datasets.
Topography I, II
Glazed stoneware, 2012
Topography I, II
Glazed stoneware, 2012
Topography I
Glazed stoneware, 2012
We are exploring ideas and implementation grants to realize Topographical tile ins
title: Topography Ceramics

content:
Encephalodome.  "Encephalodome" (working title) is an art+science game in a dome projection (planetarium) setting.
Players will wear inexpensive Electroencephalography (EEG) devices to both control and contribute to the game. They can expressively explore science through activities like concentrating, meditating, closing their eyes, and moving their bodies.
By fusing many kinds of science datasets into a vast spatial experience, “Encephalodome” will engage players in natural beauty beyond the scales of human pe
title: Encephalodome

content: ZoeKeramea.com.  Zoe Keramea is a Greek artist whose work explores enfolded surfaces through the playful use of sculpture, printmaking, drawing and ceramic techniques. She is associated with New York's The Drawing Center. Ilias created and maintains Zoe's web site. (ongoing)
title: ZoeKeramea.com

content: Every Body Looks Different.  Why are some people tall and other people short? Why does one person have darker skin and another lighter skin? What is a gene? What do our earliest relatives have to do with how we look? DuKode, in collaboration with Alexander Wright III of the Kennedy Krieger Institute, wrote and illustrated a children's book to explore these questions. Special Thanks to Mitzi Pratt for binding the book's first edition! (ongoing until publication)
title: Every Body Looks Different
